metadata.title: Dysphagia  Prader-Willi  Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Muscles, genitalia, facial features, respiratory system, skeletal system, dentition, hands and feet, and brain(1)
description: Prader-Willi  syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder with two distinct clinical phases; additional symptoms often develop during adolescence and adulthood

Hypotonic phase (fetal development and infancy) –Growth deficits and underactivity in utero(1) –Severe hypotonia leading to poor suck reflex after delivery(1,35) –Hypogonadism(1) –Cryptorchidism (absence of one or both testes from the scrotum)(1) –Dysmorphic facial features (e.g., narrow face and nasal bridge, small upturned nose, almond-shaped  eyes, thin upper lip, downturned corners of the mouth)(1) –Delayed developmental milestones(1) –Failure to thrive(1) –Decreased limb movements/limited spontaneous movements(1) –Sleep disturbances(1)  –Weak cry(1)

Hyperphagic phase (age 1–6 years) –Excessive hunger (uncontrollable hyperphagia) due to a lack of sensation of satiety (being full) as a result of hypothalamic dysfunction(1) –Hypopigmentation (light skin color)(1) –Obesity(1) –Small hands and feet(1) –Strabismus(1) (eyes are not properly aligned with each other, “lazyeye”) –Low bone mineral density(1) –Scoliosis(1) –Cognitive dysfunction(1) –Maladaptive behaviors(1) –Skin picking(1) –Hypotonia(35) –Developmental delay(35)

Adolescence/adulthood –Diabetes/reduced glucose tolerance(1) –Scoliosis(1) –Osteoporosis(1) –Psychiatric issues(1) –Global developmental delay(35) –Cognitive impairment/mild intellectual disability(35) –Dental caries(27)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Dysphagia refers to difficulty swallowing due to an inability to move food efficiently during the oral, pharyngeal, or esophageal phases of swallowing.(2) The oral phase includes sucking, chewing, and moving the food or liquid into the throat while achieving adequate lip closure. The pharyngeal phase is the initiation of the swallowing reflex, when the food is squeezed down the throat and the airway is closed off to prevent aspiration (food or liquid entering the airway) or choking. In the esophageal phase, the openings at the top and bottom of the esophagus move the food or liquid to the stomach by relaxing and tightening.(2) The speech-language pathologist (SLP) is primarily involved in the treatment and assessment of feeding and swallowing problems in infants who have PWS. Infants with PWS experience oral phase difficulties due to hypotonia of the tongue and oral cavity(4)
For detailed information about dysphagia in childhood, see  Clinical Review ... Dysphagia in Childhood  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708938  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: During a swallowing evaluation, it is of utmost importance to be aware of a patient’s pain tolerance, level of fatigue, and level of frustration. The time of day and the number of previous evaluations can affect the patient’s alertness and performance

Due to the differences between adult and pediatric swallowing issues, it is important that an SLP have competencies in dysphagia management for the particular population that he or she is evaluating and treating(7)

pathogenesis: there are four forms of pw: The first form, which is the most common (approximately 70% of cases), results from a deletion of genes on the long armof the paternal chromosome 15 in the area identified as 15q11-q13.(5,6,33,34) This form of PWS is sometimes referred to asDEL(33)

The second form of PWS, called maternal uniparental disomy (mUPD), which represents around 20% of cases, occurswhen a person inherits two copies of chromosome 15 from the mother instead of one from each parent(5,6,33)–Individuals with this form have slightly milder symptoms than individuals with other forms of the disorder(22)–A higher incidence of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) has been reported in individuals with this form of PWS(33)

The third form, accounting for about 2–4%  of cases of PWS, results from a loss of function due to a defect in the paternalchromosome 15 without an interstitial deletion; this defect prevents expression of the genes on the paternal chromosome15(5,6)
The fourth form of PWSresults from a structural rearrangement of chromosome 15(6)
See Description , above, for phases of the disease
risk factors: Having a father with a genetic mutation on chromosome 15(5,6)

overall contraindications precautions: SLPs are required to have graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically in dysphagia assessment and treatment(7)
To perform a videofluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS), SLPs must have established competencies in the use and storage of barium used in VFSSs(2)

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and/or penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and patient’s family are aware of potential aspiration risks and educated about prevention strategies when appropriate. Infants with PWS are at risk for silent aspiration related to hypotonia and dysphagia(4)

A patient’s culture and native language should be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination questions and materials. Feeding practices and foods differ considerably across cultures; the patient’s and family’s view of dysphagia, appropriate assessments, and appropriate treatments will vary accordingly as well(31)
Be aware of dietary restrictions or preferences and any food allergies when choosing food and liquid for use in swallowing assessment(s)(31)

While infants with PWS are at risk for malnutrition due to poor sucking ability, children with PWS are at risk for being overweight due to uncontrollable hyperphagia. Weight gain in children with PWS is further affected by a slow metabolism, low muscle tone, lethargy, low energy expenditure, and unbalanced neuroendocrine functioning(1)

Development of an individualized family service plan (IFSP; ages 0–3) or an individual education program (IEP; school-aged)  in collaboration with the parents and school personnel is essential for children with PWS to address learning, language, and cognitive problems as well as feeding and motor problems in the home or school environment. In addition, this plan can assist early childhood or school personnel in modifying activities that might be otherwise harmful or unsafe for the child

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when PWS was first diagnosed; in which stage is the patient currently?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of PWS varies from patient to patient. Possible medical interventions for Orthopedic treatment for scoliosis (present in up to 80% of patients with PWS)(1) Growth hormone (GH) treatment for growth and related issues(1) (without GH intervention, severe obesity from overeating can occur by the age of 2 years) According to the consensus guidelines from the Growth Hormone Research Society workshop summary published in 2013, GH should be considered for individuals with PWS along with dietary, environmental, and lifestyle interventions.(32) There is no consensus on age of initiation of GH except that it should be initiated prior to the onset of obesity, which typically occurs around the age of 2 years(32) Feeding tubes (orogastric, nasogastric, gastrostomy, jejunostomy)/enteral feeding
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Ask a pharmacist or doctor about the side effects of these medications (e.g., loss of appetite).Medications prescribed for GH(22) Antidepressants, antipsychotics, and/or mood stabilizers for psychosocial impairment when present(22)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnosis of PWS is made based on a consensus of clinical criteria and genetic testing(1)

There are major criteria weighted at 1 point each (including characteristic facial features, intellectual disability, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, neonatal/infantile hypotonia, feeding problems/failure to thrive in infancy, and rapid weight gain between ages 1 and 6 years), minor criteria weighted at 0.5 points each (decreased fetal movement/ infantile lethargy, behavior problems, sleep disturbances, short stature, hypopigmentation, small hands/feet for age, narrow hands, esotropia [one or both eyes turns inward]/myopia, thick saliva, speech defects, and skin picking), and supportive criteria that increase suspicion for diagnosis but are not scored (high pain threshold, less than typical vomiting when the patient is ill or is given an emetic, scoliosis/kyphosis, early adrenarche [sexual maturity], osteoporosis, unusual skill with jigsaw puzzles, and normal neuromuscular studies)(22)
Children under age 3 years must have a score of 5 points, 4 of which come from major criteria,in addition to a positive genetic test(22)
Children aged 3 to 8 years must have at 8 points, 5 of which come from major criteria,in addition to a positive genetic test(22)
An evaluation for dysphagia can include any or all the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient have a history of pneumonia or respiratory infections? -with certain textures of foods or liquids? -in different environments? -as meals progress? -during certain times of day? -if fatigued? -with environmental distractions?  -after taking certain medications? -Are emotional outbursts sparked by a change in routine or expectations, or cognitive challenges?(23,24)
history of present illness.body chart: Review the patient’s chart and weight history and note any significant changes in weight
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Feeding problems in infants with PWS are primarily due to hypotonia of the muscles used for swallowing(4)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Patients with PWS often have an increased tolerance for pain, which increases risk of injury(22) -It is important to ask caregivers about the way in which the patient reacts to painful situations (e.g., shots at the doctor, falling and scraping one’s knee) to gauge the patient’s pain threshold(22)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); document any history of coughing while eating and/or increasing difficulty as the meal progresses
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Sleep disturbances common among patients with PWS include excessive daytime sleepiness (related to hormone deficiencies) and sleep apnea (related to obesity)(1,22)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Symptoms related to PWS include temperature regulation difficulties, susceptibility to infection, and health problems secondary to obesity(1)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the respiratory status of the patient, including vital capacity, and include use of supplemental oxygen, need for mechanical ventilation, or presence of a tracheostomy tubeDocument any behavioral symptoms that indicate psychosocial disturbances -Patients with PWS exhibit a range of behaviors at different stages of development. Infants have been described as happy, cooperative, affectionate, friendly, and compliant. Maladaptive behaviors typically emerge in childhood and include skin picking, verbal perseveration, stubbornness, obsessions, temper tantrums, impulsivity, disobedience, and excessive sleep.(1) Psychosocial problems related to hyperphagia include excessive hoarding and inappropriate social behaviors. Other psychosocial issues, including withdrawal, underactivity, and lack of energy, worsen with age. Adolescents with PWS often experience depression and anxiety(30) -Authors of a study conducted in the United States reported that poor maternal quality of life was related to the presence of maladaptive behaviors, but not adaptive or cognitive skills, of the child with PWS(36)Document results of audiological screenings or tests Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous swallowing difficulties, respiratory difficulties, communication difficulties, motor disorders, cognitive deficits, or behavioral difficulties
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Refer to medical charts and ask patient or patient’s family about other problems, including behavior difficulties, hearing loss, vision problems, heart problems, communication difficulties, and memory loss Obesity-related  problems in PWS include diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, chronic venous insufficiency with foot and leg ulcers, cellulitis, sleep apnea, and hypoventilation(22) Skin-picking  can lead to infected wounds(22)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient or caregivers about other symptoms the patient is experiencing (e.g., excessive throat clearing, coughing while eating)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider include receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, hospital, or clinic based? Does the patient attend school? Where does the patient eat? What types/textures of food? What is the patient’s eating schedule?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate or to eat. Does the patient feed self? Is the patient limited to eating only certain textures of food?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document who patient lives with (e.g., family, siblings). Who prepares patient’s food?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Early in life, patients with PWS are at risk for malnourishment and failure to thrive; later in life, patients are at risk for obesity(22,26) –For adults, note BMI(22,26) –Document height and weight; for children with PWS, note percentile on the standardized growth chart as well as growth charts developed for children with PWS(26)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use any adaptive devices for mobility, communication, or eating (e.g., specialized bottles or nipples)?(35)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Note any posture abnormalities that might interfere with swallowing. Scoliosis is present in up to 80% of patients with PWS(1)Document if the patient self-feeds, self-monitors  food intake, and/or prepares food independently (when age appropriate)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: The SLP should refer to any audiological or vision examinations as indicated
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Infants and toddlers present with weak cry, poor oral motor skills, and delayed onset of speech and language.(1) School-aged  children with PWS present with many sound errors and expressive and receptive language delay(35) –For detailed information on speech and language assessment and treatment for patients with PWS, see  Clinical Review ...Communication Disorders  ; CINAHL Topic ID NumberExamine motor function and tone as it relates to positioning for feeding and swallowingExamine the structure and the range, rate, coordination, and symmetry of movement of the lips, facial musculature, tongue, pharynx, and larynx -reduced lingual and labial strength and ROM(27) -dry mouth or thick saliva(9,27) -constant drooling(27) -asymmetrical facial expressions(27) -mouth-breathing(9) -teeth grinding/excessive tooth wear(9) -velopharyngeal insufficiency following adenotonsillectomy for obstructive sleep apnea(25) -For detailed information on velopharyngeal insufficiency, see  Clinical Review ... Velopharyngeal Dysfunction  ;T708864
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Children with PWS have cognitive difficulties, with an average IQ score of 70 (range = 50–100).  Adaptive behavior skills are often lower than would be expected for cognitive ability due to food-related  behaviors.(1) Refer to completed cognitive or psychological assessments
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Feeding development and swallowing function should be evaluated through a combination of clinical and instrumental examinations. Nursing and parental input as well as input from the medical team should also be considered to determine infant readiness for oral feeding –CSEBefore feeding, the infant should be observed for signs that indicate readiness for feeding, such as alert and awakening behavior, mouthing and stable breathing, and color. If the infant is not alert, the SLP should consider postponing the assessment(11)  -Nonnutritive sucking (NNS) ability should be examined first to evaluate an infant’s awareness, rooting, latching, and the coordination of suction and compression.Normal NNS consists of 2 sucks per second and 6 to 8 sucks per swallow.(11)If the infant is able to be fed orally, observe the caregiver feeding the infant. Note the infant’s response to the nipple touching the lips and the presence of a rooting reflex. Observe the infant’s ability to find, accept, and latch onto the nipple. Evaluate specific characteristics of sucking, including the coordination of sucking-swallowing-breathing1 movements, gasping, coughing, and choking(11)There are several clinical assessment scales and checklists to evaluate infants and children; however, no universally accepted feeding assessment tool exists. Scales, surveys, and checklists are commonly used in the CSE but often do not include normative data, standardization, validation, or guidelines for interpretation. SLP knowledge of normal oral motor development and feeding function are essential when evaluating infants and childrenEvaluation of an infant’s ability to suck on a bottle and/or breast. Includes assessment of infant’s feeding history, oral motor skills, oral tactile responses, suck-swallow-breath coordination, general motor control, and general physical state during feeding and swallowing(12)Evaluation of sucking in infants (up to 3 months of age). Aspects of sucking behavior are classified as normal, disorganized, or dysfunctional(13)Rating scale that examines swallowing and voice in children up to 2 years of age. Ratings include duration of the meal, amount of intake, food consistencies, positioning, sucking from a nipple, sipping from a cup, and coordination of suck-swallow-breath(14)Lip, cheek, tongue, and jaw movement are rated during a typical meal. This scale can be used with children from 1 year of age through adults(15)In-depthT709064A VFSS is performed when the dysphagia team has concerns about the pharyngeal phase of swallowing and the complete swallowing sequence. A VFSS is completed in collaboration with a physician (radiologist or physiatrist).(7) The assessment must be age-appropriate  with regard to positioning, presentation of food and liquid, and viscosity of material.(7) The patient eats and drinks a variety of developmentally appropriate liquids and solids mixed with barium while images are recorded with videofluorography. All patients should be examined in the lateral and frontal positions to gain information on movements of the swallow and symmetry of bolus flow and pharyngeal wall contraction. The SLP examines for the presence of aspiration and the effectiveness of presenting different food consistencies or of modifying posture.(7) In contrast to the CSE, VFSS provides critical information on the pharyngeal phase of the swallow.(17) Given the unnatural surroundings, swallowing function observed during a VFSS is not necessarily identical to that used at mealtimes.(18) Other variables that influence swallowing function include anxiety, fatigue, and medications.(16) Due to the harmful effects of ionizing radiation on children, a repeat VFSS should only be considered when there are specific questions that require answers from a repeat study; a VFSS should not be used frequently to monitor changes in swallowing(16) -In a study conducted in the United States of 23 VFSS studies performed with 10 infants with PWS (many infants underwent multiple VFSSs), researchers found a high incidence of dysphagia. Nine of the infants exhibited aspiration during at least one of the VFSSs; aspiration occurred in 87% of the VFSSs conducted and pharyngeal residue was present in 71%. Every instance of aspiration observed in these 23 VFSS studies was silent. Researchers highly recommended evaluating infants with PWS with a VFSS or other instrumental evaluation of swallowing rather than a CSE alone(38)(16) -Lip closure (ability to contain a liquid bolus) -Lingual elevation (the back of the tongue should be slightly elevated) -Tongue-to-palatal  seal -Bolus preparation/mastication -Bolus transport/movement of the tongue (movement of the bolus to the back of the oral cavity)  -Initiation of the pharyngeal swallow (swallow should be initiated when the bolus reaches the region of the posterior oral cavity) -Soft palate elevation and retraction -Laryngeal elevation -Anterior hyoid excursion -Laryngeal closure -Pharyngeal contraction -Pharyngoesophageal segment opening -Tongue base retraction -Epiglottic inversion -Esophageal clearanceModifiedT709077A FEES is performed to evaluate the anatomy and physiology of the pharynx and the larynx, pharyngeal swallow function, and the patient’s ability to manage secretions and swallow foods and liquids.(7) In addition, it can be used to explore a variety of diagnostic interventions, such as varying bolus consistency, varying posture, or making use of visual feedback for reinforcement.(19) After the insertion of the endoscope, the patient can engage in normal feeding behavior during the evaluation. Food must be light in color to enhance visibility (e.g., milk, puddings, yogurt, bread). A FEES is sometimes preferred over VFSS when patients have safety issues related to radiation exposure or when they need frequent retesting. Due to the invasive nature of the procedure, it can be difficult to obtain accurate representation of a normal swallow in young children -For detailed information on endoscopic assessment of swallowing, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicInfant sucking and oral transit times can be examined by ultrasonography, an instrumental procedure involving transducers that use high-frequency  sound waves to create images. In infants and children, the transducer is placed under the chin as the patient swallows liquid or food. The ultrasonographic scanner can display images of the nipple, tongue surface, hard and soft palates, and hyoid during infant feeding(7)
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with PWS are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Patients with dysphagia are at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Inform the patient and family/caregivers of the potential for aspiration and educate about prevention strategies when appropriate
It is important to consider eating habits, food preferences, dietary restrictions, and cultural influences on eating to maximize nutritional intake

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocol

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Dysphagia diagnosis and management are based on the results of a comprehensive assessment that is performed by an SLP in collaboration with a transdisciplinary team that might include a pediatrician, a dietician, an occupational therapist (OT), a physical therapist (PT), a respiratory therapist, an otolaryngologist, a radiologist, a social worker, a gastroenterologist, and a neurologist. Each discipline will provide specific input and expertise on the patient’s swallowing problems and nutritional requirements. The primary concern is to maintain and maximize the patient’s health status(7)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The physician should rule out other causes of infant hypotonia, such as Angelman syndrome. PWS is the genetic mirror (sometimes called sister syndrome) of Angelman syndrome (both affecting chromosome 15; however, Angelman syndrome results from deletion of the maternal portion of chromosome 15 or paternal UPD).(6) Other conditions that include symptoms of obesity and developmental disability should also be ruled out, such as Cohen syndrome and Bardet Biedl syndrome(5)
prognosis: Death in patients with PWS occurs in higher rates than in the general population as a result of complications of obesity, including cardiovascular disease, sleep apnea, shock due to gastric dilation, and pneumonia associated with aspiration(22)
There is an increased risk of death due to choking in patients with PWS(22)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to an OT, PT, nutritionist, respiratory therapist, social worker, endocrinologist, neurologist, otolaryngologist, radiologist, oral hygienist, or gastroenterologist as necessary. Refer patient and/or caregivers to a psychologist or counselor if signs of depression are present
treatment summary: Nipple selection for bottle-feeding:  Adaptive bottles and specialized bottle nipples are often used to slow the flow of liquid or change the way in which liquid is delivered into the oral cavity for infants with PWS.(35) Nipple characteristics such as the shape or material of the nipple and size of the hole can be selected to influence fluid flow; however, there is little evidence to support the use of a particular type of nipple to improve bottle-feeding performance in preterm infants. Nipples are often selected based upon personal preference and clinical experience

Chin and cheek support:  To stabilize the jaw when the infant exhibits hypotonia and excessive jaw shifting, the middle finger can be placed under the chin and the index finger between the chin and lower lip during bottle-feeding(7)

External pacing:  External pacing or paced feeding protocols have been trialed to assist the preterm infant in coordinating breathing and sucking patterns.(7) Preterm infants may use “transitional” sucking patterns that are not coordinated with breathing. These immature sucking patterns can lead to coughing, choking, bradycardia, apnea, and fatigue during feeding. Paced feeding involves removing the nipple from the mouth after every three to five sucks to encourage 3- to 5-second breathing pauses

Feeding schedules: The two primary options for feeding schedules are responsive feeding (feeding an infant based on his or her behaviors that indicate hunger and satiation) and scheduled interval feeding (infant is fed at scheduled times). Authors of a systematic review that included 9 RCTs compared the effects of both types of feeding schedules for preterm infants and determined that there are insufficient data at present to guide clinical practice. There is some indication that responsive feeding with preterm infants leads to full oral feeding (i.e., no need for tube feed supplementation) more quickly than interval feeding; however, larger, better designed trials are necessary to confirm this finding(20)

Oral sensory motor therapy/oral stimulation:  Oral and facial stimulation in preterm infants through use of auditory, tactile, visual, and vestibular intervention is associated with faster transition to oral feeding, reduced length of hospital stay, and improved weight gains(3,8)
Oral motor exercises : There is no evidence to support the use of oral motor exercises for dysphagia rehabilitation in children with neurological impairment

Nonnutritive sucking:  NNS refers to pacifier sucking. The objective for NNS is to assist the infant to develop coordinated sucking behaviors in preparation for oral feeding –The authors of a systematic review examined 12 studies to determine the effects of NNS on major clinical variables for preterm infants: length of hospital stay, transition to bottle-feeding,  bottle-feeding  performance, weight gain, energy intake, heart rate, oxygen saturation, intestinal transit time, age at full oral feeds, and behavioral state.(21) The reviewers concluded that NNS led to a significantly decreased duration of hospital stay, reduced time for transition from gavage to full oral feeding, and reduced time for transition from start of oral feeding to full oral feeding. There was no consistent benefit on other clinical variables(21)

Kangaroo mother care (KMC):  The primary component of KMC is skin-to-skin  contact and breast-feeding  support for a mother and a newborn infant. KMC is associated with lower rates of infant mortality(10)

Feeding tubes (orogastric, nasogastric, gastrostomy, jejunostomy)/enteral feeding:  When oral feeding does not provide sufficient oral intake for patients with PWS, enteral feeds may be delivered through a catheter passed through the nose (nasogastric), through the mouth (orogastric), and into the stomach (gastrostomy) or small intestine (jejunostomy). Even while tube feeding is required, most patients with PWS continue to receive oral feedings as a supplemental nutritional source or as swallow rehabilitation. Authors of a Cochrane systematic review examined three trials comparing the use of nasogastric tubes vs. orogastric tubes for preterm infants and found that there was no evidence to support the use of one over the other or to guide clinical practice(37)

For detailed information on treatment of dysphagia in childhood, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Childhood , referenced above . improved swallowing ability: Presence of aspiration (measured by presence of fevers, X-rays)
improved nutrition and hydration: Measures of liquid intake and skin turgor (refers to skin elasticity; poor skin turgor is a sign of dehydration)
Patient and family/caregiver compliance with patient’s optimal diet

maintenance or prevention: Patient and caregiver education about dysphagia, including the importance of nutrition and hydration, should be initiated if the patient is having swallowing difficulties
patient education: It is important to educate the parent(s)/caregiver(s) of a patient with PWS throughout the intervention process.(28) Parents and caregivers of patients with PWS generally desire to be educated on the various intervention strategies for behavioral, eating, and communication problems in patients with PWS, preferring active strategies over passive ones(28) Strategies for managing overeating in patients with PWS include restricting access to food, keeping the patient otherwise occupied, and establishing routines around meal and snack times(29)
